title: Application of Operation Research in Software Engineering?
description:
Hi fellow lobsters, I am a first-year Ph.D. student in Operation Research looking for research topics. I am always interested in building software, so I would like to work in the context of software engineering. As experienced programmers, can you share some open problems in software that can potentially be tackled by tools from Operation Research?

For example, OS kernels have to make a lot of decisions, e.g. which thread to switch to when CPUs are overloaded, which page to evict when memory is running low, and which process to kill when the OOM. Do we have a theory for these decisions, or are they just heuristic-based? In the latter case, can we achieve better performance/fairness by implementing some data-driven decision-making or stochastic control algorithms with eBPF? On the application level, I‚Äôm thinking about SQL databases, whose interaction with the network or filesystem could probably use some optimization from queuing theory, but maybe that has already been done.

My ultimate goal is to make some practical algorithms or software packages that people can use, rather than doing theoretical analysis. Please tell me where can I make a difference!
description_plain:
Hi fellow lobsters, I am a first-year Ph.D. student in Operation Research looking for research topics. I am always interested in building software, so I would like to work in the context of software engineering. As experienced programmers, can you share some open problems in software that can potentially be tackled by tools from Operation Research?

For example, OS kernels have to make a lot of decisions, e.g. which thread to switch to when CPUs are overloaded, which page to evict when memory is running low, and which process to kill when the OOM. Do we have a theory for these decisions, or are they just heuristic-based? In the latter case, can we achieve better performance/fairness by implementing some data-driven decision-making or stochastic control algorithms with [eBPF](https://lwn.net/Articles/941614/)? On the application level, I'm thinking about SQL databases, whose interaction with the network or filesystem could probably use some optimization from queuing theory, but maybe that has already been done.

My ultimate goal is to make some practical algorithms or software packages that people can use, rather than doing theoretical analysis. Please tell me where can I make a difference!

Nue: A React/Vue/Vite/Astro alternative
description:
Author here. I‚Äôve been working on this for the past ~12 months, lately full-time.

I wasn‚Äôt happy with the current state of web development, so I decided to write a completely new ecosystem from scratch. I went back to the ‚Äúgood old days‚Äù, and took advantage of innovations like progressive enhancement, separation of concerns, and semantic web design. The result is a powerful alternative to frameworks like Vue, React, and Svelte as well as toolchains like Vite, Next.js, and Astro.

Nue ecosystem is work-in-progress and today I‚Äôm releasing the tiny, but powerful core: Nue JS. It‚Äôs an extremely small (2.3kb minzipped) JavaScript library for building user interfaces. It‚Äôs like React or Vue, but there are no hooks, effects, props, or other unusual abstractions on your way. Know the basics of HTML, CSS, and JavaScript and you can build server-side components and reactive interfaces with ease.

All projects will be released under the MIT license.

Happy to answer any questions.
description_plain:
Author here. I've been working on this for the past ~12 months, lately full-time.

I wasn't happy with the current state of web development, so I decided to write a completely new ecosystem from scratch. I went back to the "good old days", and took advantage of innovations like progressive enhancement, separation of concerns, and semantic web design. The result is a powerful alternative to frameworks like Vue, React, and Svelte as well as toolchains like Vite, Next.js, and Astro.

Nue ecosystem is work-in-progress and today I'm releasing the tiny, but powerful core: Nue JS. It's an extremely small (2.3kb minzipped) JavaScript library for building user interfaces. It's like React or Vue, but there are no hooks, effects, props, or other unusual abstractions on your way. Know the basics of HTML, CSS, and JavaScript and you can build server-side components and reactive interfaces with ease.

All projects will be released under the MIT license.

Happy to answer any questions.
